revision.text:
:''For the Sydney station, see [[Fish Market tram stop]].'' [[File:HAL fish market.jpg|thumb|A fish stall in HAL market, [[Bangalore]]]] [[File:H-mart - fish department - Mackerel - 2.JPG|thumb|Fish department in [[H Mart]] store in [[Fairfax, Virginia]] with [[Mackerel]], [[Bluefish]], [[Porgy (fish)|Porgy]], [[Whiting (fish)|Whiting]] and many other fish.]] A '''fish market''' is a [[marketplace]] for selling [[fish products]]. It can be dedicated to wholesale trade between [[Fisherman|fishermen]] and fish [[merchant]]s, or to the sale of [[seafood]] to individual consumers, or to both. Retail fish markets, a type of [[wet market]], often sell [[street food]] as well.
Fish markets range in size from small fish stalls, such as the one in the photo at the right, to the great [[Tsukiji fish market]] in Tokyo, turning over about 660,000 tonnes a year.<ref name="Clover">Clover C (2008) [https://books.google.com/books?id=OMY-gEKMod8C&pg=PA165 ''The End of the Line: How Overfishing Is Changing the World and What We Eat''] Page 165. University of California Press, {{ISBN|978-0-520-25505-0}}.</ref>
The term ''fish market'' can also refer to the process of [[fish marketing]] in general, but this article is concerned with physical marketplaces. __TOC__
==History and development== [[File:Jan Brueghel the Elder-Great Fish market.jpg|thumb|The ''Great Fish Market'', painted by [[Jan Brueghel the Elder]]]] Fish markets were known in antiquity.<ref>Rauch JE and Casella A (2001) [https://books.google.com/books?id=b_QHqOhGlfcC&pg=PA157 ''Networks and markets''] Page 157. Russell Sage Foundation, {{ISBN|978-0-87154-700-2}}.</ref> They served as a [[public space]] where large numbers of people could gather and discuss current events and local [[politics]].
Because seafood is quick to [[Decomposition|spoil]], fish markets are historically most often found in seaside towns. Once [[ice]] or other simple cooling methods became available, some were also established in large inland cities that had good [[trade route]]s to the coast.
[[File:Selling fish in a Quebec Market.jpg|thumb|Selling fish in a Quebec Market, c. 1845.]]
Since [[refrigeration]] and rapid [[transport]] became available in the 19th and 20th century, fish markets can technically be established at any place. However, because modern trade [[logistics]] in general has shifted away from marketplaces and towards [[retail]] outlets, such as [[supermarkets]], most seafood worldwide is now sold to consumers through these venues, like most other [[foodstuff]]s.
Consequently, most major fish markets now mainly deal with wholesale trade, and the existing major fish retail markets continue to operate as much for traditional reasons as for commercial ones. Both types of fish markets are often [[tourist attraction]]s as well.
==Notable fish markets== [[File:Tsukiji.FrozenTuna.jpg|thumb|Frozen [[tuna]] in the [[Tsukiji fish market]], Tokyo]] [[File:Self-serve display at a fish market.jpg|thumb|Self-serve display at a New England fish market. Customers use tongs to select their fish, then place it in a plastic tub for transfer to either the checkout counter or the fileting station.]] The following is an incomplete list of notable fish markets. (See also [[:Category:Fish markets|a list of fish market articles]].)
===Operative markets=== * [[Tsukiji fish market]], [[Tokyo]], Japan; the world's largest fish market, marketing about 660,000 tonnes a year.<ref name="Clover" /> * [[La Nueva Viga Market]], [[Mexico City]], Mexico; the world's second largest fish market. Marketing from 250,000 up to 550,000 tons of seafood a year. * [[Sydney Fish Market]], [[Sydney]], Australia the world's third largest fish market for volume sold and second largest in terms of variety. * [[Mercamadrid]], [[Madrid]], Spain; the world's fourth largest fish market, marketing about 220,000 tonnes a year.<ref name="Clover" /> * [[Billingsgate Fish Market]], [[London]], England, United Kingdom. * [[Busan Cooperative Fish Market]], [[Busan]], [[South Korea]]. * [[Feskekôrka]], [[Gothenburg]], Sweden. * [[Fulton Fish Market]], [[New York, New York|New York]], United States. * [[Maine Avenue Fish Market]], [[Washington, D.C.]], USA. * [[Aberdeen floating village#The fish marketing organization|Aberdeen Seafood Market]], [[Aberdeen, Hong Kong|Aberdeen]], [[Hong Kong Island]], [[Hong Kong]]. * [[Taipei Fish Market]], [[Taipei]], [[Taiwan]].
===Historical markets=== *[[Scania Market]], a historical annual market at the [[Falsterbo Peninsula]]
==See also== {{portal|Food}} {{div col|colwidth=30em}} * [[Commercial fishing]] * [[Fishmonger]] * [[Fish products]] * [[Fishwife]] * [[History of fishing]] * [[List of fish dishes]] * [[List of seafood companies]] * [[List of seafood dishes]] * [[List of seafood restaurants]] * [[Overfishing]] * [[Wild fisheries]] {{div col end}}
==Notes== {{reflist}}
==References== * Bellamy JC (1843) [https://books.google.com/books?id=Jt8-AAAAYAAJ ''The housekeeper's guide to the fish-market for each month of the year''] Issue 33171 of ''Goldsmiths'-Kress library of economic literature'', Longman, Brown, Green & Longmans. * Bestor TC (2004) [https://books.google.com/books?id=Tzix2jithpQC&pg=PR11 ''Tsukiji: the fish market at the center of the world''] In PE Lilienthal, ''California studies'', Volume 11, University of California Press, {{ISBN|978-0-520-22024-9}}. * Le Blanch J (2003) [https://books.google.com/books?id=XLsp9ACXGCIC&pg=PA30 The Global fish market and the need for multilateral fishing disciplines] In: Leonard B (ed) ''Overfishing: A Global Challenge'', Diane Publishing, {{ISBN|978-1-4289-6711-3}}. *Paula Mónaco Felipe (April 11, 2008). "La Nueva Viga, paseo marino en el DF fuera de las guías turísticas" [La Nueva Viga, marine walk in the Federal District outside of tour guide books]. La Jornada (in Spanish) (Mexico City). Retrieved March 13, 2011. * Crother C (2005) [https://books.google.com/books?id=iK6y_Fhq80cC&pg=PR7 ''Catch!: A Fishmonger's Guide to Greatness''] Berrett-koehler Series, Berrett-Koehler Publishers, {{ISBN|978-1-57675-323-1}}. * Graddy K (2006) [http://people.brandeis.edu/~kgraddy/published%20papers/GraddyK_jep2006.pdf "The Fulton fish market"] ''Journal of Economic Perspectives'', '''20'''(2): 207–220. * Kirman, Alan P. and Vriend, Nicolaas J. (2000) [https://books.google.com/books?id=5D4V5DwKeKgC&pg=PA33 "Learning to be loyal: A study of the Marseille fish market"]. In: Domenico Delli Gatti, [[Mauro Gallegati]], Alan P. Kirman, ''Interaction and market structure: essays on heterogeneity in economics'', Volume 484. Springer, {{ISBN|978-3-540-66979-1}}. * Maniatis GC (2000) [https://www.jstor.org/pss/1291831 "The Organizational Setup and Functioning of the Fish Market in Tenth-Century Constantinople"] ''Dumbarton Oaks Papers'', '''54''': 13-42. * Porcù Leide (2005) [http://www.degruyter.com/view/j/humr.2005.18.issue-1/humr.2005.18.1.69/humr.2005.18.1.69.xml "Fishy business: Humor in a Sardinian fish market"] ''International Journal of Humor Research'', '''18'''(1): 69–102. {{doi|10.1515/humr.2005.18.1.69}} * Sophie S and Håkan H (2009) [http://swepub.kb.se/bib/swepub:oai:services.scigloo.org:94715?tab2=abs&language=en "Behind the fish market facade"] ''The IMP Journal'', '''3'''(1): 50-74. * Sancar Seckiner's new book DZ Uzerine Notlar, published Dec. 2014, highlights historic connection between two important fish markets in the world :Billingsgate-Yenikapı. {{ISBN|978-605-4579-83-9}}.
== External links == {{commons category|Fish markets}} *{{Internet Archive film clip|id=nyc_ghetto_fish_market_1903|description=of a fish market in New York in 1903}} * [https://books.google.com/books?id=udYCAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA47&dq=%22Fish+market%22&hl=en&ei=iLByTcDdNIXRcZfPzfgC&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CDYQ6AEwADgU#v=onepage&q=%22Fish%20market%22&f=false Fish out of water: A guide to city fishmongers] ''New York Magazine'', 10 April 1978.
{{fishing industry topics}} {{fisheries and fishing}}

revision.text:
{{Expert needed|Gymnastics|date=February 2009}} The '''Gienger''' is a [[gymnastics]] skill performed on the [[uneven bars]] for women and the [[high bar]] for men. It is named after [[Germany|German]] [[gymnast]] [[Eberhard Gienger]]. The release move looks like a half-turn layout "flyaway" above the bar to catch the same bar. Its [[Code of Points (artistic gymnastics)|COP]] reference is 3.405 and it is a D element.
The skill typically begins from a handstand followed by a swing backward and release after 3/4 of a revolution around the bar. The skill begins as a backward salto with the gymnast completing a 1/2 twist (180°) before regrasp on the same bar that was released. The Gienger can be done with either a piked (traditional) or stretched body form. A variation on the Gienger is the Def (COP 3.605), which is a G-rated element and is identical to the Gienger except that instead of a 1/2 twist (180°), the gymnast performs 1 1/2 twists (540°) before regrasp on the bar.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fig-docs.com/Media/Codes%20of%20Points%202013%20-%202016/WAG/2013-2016%20WAG%20CoP.pdf |title=2013 Code Of Points Women’S Artistic Gymnastics |publisher=FIG }}</ref>
Gienger saltos are technically similar to Deltchev saltos, with the latter initiating the 1/2 twist before initiating the Arabian (which is also usually straddled rather than piked or stretched).
Some of the female gymnasts that perform the Gienger are [[Nastia Liukin]], [[Eugenia Popa]], and [[Shawn Johnson]].
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Gymnastics manoeuvres]]

اســتــاد حــمــد الــكــبــيــر | nickname = Al-Arabi Stadium | image = Doha-grand-hamad-stadium-90685.jpg | fullname = Grand Hamad Stadium | location = [[Doha]], [[Qatar]] | coordinates = 25°15'31"N 51°31'19"E | broke_ground = | built = | opened = | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Al-Arabi SC (Qatar)|Al-Arabi Sport Club]] | operator = | surface = [[Lawn|Grass]] | construction_cost = | architect = | structural engineer= | services engineer = | general_contractor = | project_manager = | main_contractors = | former_names = | tenants = [[Al-Arabi SC (Qatar)|Al-Arabi SC]] | seating_capacity = 13,000 | dimensions = }} The '''Grand Hamad Stadium''' ({{lang-ar|استاد حمد الكبير}}), also known as the Al-Arabi Sports Club Stadium, is a [[multi-purpose stadium]] in [[Doha]], [[Qatar]]. It is currently used mostly for [[association football|football]] matches. The football team [[Al-Arabi SC (Qatar)|Al-Arabi SC]] play there. The stadium holds 13,000 people. The stadium was used extensively during the [[2006 Asian Games]], and was a venue for several different sports; these include [[Football at the 2006 Asian Games|football]], [[Table Tennis at the 2006 Asian Games|table tennis]], [[Rugby at the 2006 Asian Games|rugby sevens]] and [[Fencing at the 2006 Asian Games|fencing]]. [[Iraq national football team]] played their [[2014 FIFA World Cup qualification (AFC)]] games at the ground. Now they use the Stadium as a home for [[Yemen national football team]] in [[2018 FIFA World Cup qualification (AFC)]]. ==FIFA World Cup Qualification Matches== Fifa World Cup Qualification Matches Women: Hoofdklasse | website = {{URL|https://www.hdmonline.nl}} | kit_alt1 = | pattern_la1 = | pattern_b1 = _navystripes | pattern_ra1 = | pattern_sh1 = | pattern_so1 = _hoops_white | leftarm1 = 000080 | body1 = ffffff | rightarm1 = 000080 | shorts1 = 000080 | socks1 = 000080 | kit_alt2 = | pattern_la2 = | pattern_b2 = _red_stripes | pattern_ra2 = | pattern_sh2 = | pattern_so2 = _hoops_white | leftarm2 = ff0000 | body2 = ffffff | rightarm2 = ff0000 | shorts2 = 000080 | socks2 = ff0000 | kit_alt3 = | pattern_la3 = | pattern_b3 = | pattern_ra3 = | pattern_sh3 = | pattern_so3 = | pattern_name3 = | leftarm3 = | body3 = | rightarm3 = | shorts3 = | socks3 = }} '''Haagsche Delftsche Mixed''' ('''HDM''') is a [[field hockey]] club from [[The Hague]]. The club was founded on February 8, 1908, when students from [[Delft]] wanted to play hockey with their girlfriends from [[The Hague]]. The first men's team won the Dutch national title in 1924, 1930, 1931, 1935, 1941, 1942 and – for the last time – in 1992. Currently the first men's plays in the second division, which is called "Promotieklasse", the first women's team plays in the top league, called "Hoofdklasse". ==Notable internationals from HDM== [[File:Giselle Kañevsky.jpg|thumb|180px|[[Giselle Kañevsky]]]] * [[Carina Benninga]] * [[Marc Benninga]] * [[Wendy Fortuin]] * [[Russell Garcia (field hockey)|Russell Garcia]] * [[Julian Halls]] * [[Nicole Koolen]] * [[Martine Ohr]] * [[Wouter van Pelt]] * [[Koen Pijpers]] * [[Hanneke Smabers]] * [[Minke Smabers]] * [[Macha van der Vaart]] * [[Ingrid Wolff]] * [[Giselle Kañevsky]] ==References== [[Category:Haagsche Delftsche Mixed| ]] [[Category:Dutch field hockey clubs]] [[Category:Field hockey clubs established in 1908]] [[Category:Sport in The Hague]] [[Category:1908 establishments in the Netherlands]] {{Fieldhockey-team-stub}} {{Netherlands-sport-stub}}

{{EngvarB|date=September 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2014}} {{Infobox boxer |name= Lauryn Eagle |image= Lauryn Eagle, 2012.jpg |caption= Eagle in July 2012 |nickname= |height = {{convert|1.74|m|ftin|abbr=on}} |weight= [[Lightweight]]
[[Super featherweight]] |nationality = Australian |birth_date= {{Birth date and age|df=yes|1987|12|11}} |birth_place= [[Randwick, New South Wales]] |style= [[Orthodox stance|Orthodox]] |total= 20{{cite web|url=http://boxrec.com/list_bouts.php?human_id=545699&cat=boxer |title=Lauryn Eagle – Boxer |publisher=Boxrec.com |accessdate=23 July 2012}} |wins= 15 |losses= 4 |draws= 1 |no contests= 0 |KO= 7 |}} '''Lauryn Eagle''' (born 11 December 1987) is an Australian professional [[boxer]] and [[water skiing]] champion.{{cite web|url=http://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/sport/gallery/gallery-e6freye9-1225868786845?page=1 |title=Lauryn Eagle |work=The Daily Telegraph|location=Australia |date=17 July 2012|accessdate=23 July 2012}} She was on [[The Celebrity Apprentice Australia (season 2)|The Celebrity Apprentice Australia]]{{cite web|url=http://www.couriermail.com.au/entertainment/confidential/lauryn-eagle-on-the-behaviour-and-ego-of-celebrity-apprentice-co-contestant-tania-zaetta/story-e6freq7o-1226344049273 |title=Lauryn Eagle on the behaviour and ego of Celebrity Apprentice co-contestant Tania Zaetta | Entertainment News Queensland |publisher=The Courier-Mail |date=2 May 2012 |accessdate=23 July 2012}} and is a former [[Miss Teen International]] 2004. ==Water skiing== Coming from a [[water skiing]] family, her father Peter won the Australian title eleven times and sister Sarah placed second at the 2007 World Championships. She first learnt to ski at the age of four and started racing when she was nine years old. In 2003, she placed second in the Junior Division and at the next World Championships in 2005 she won the women's division title in the [[World water skiing champions#List of Ski Racing World Champions|F2 class]]. In 2006, she won the Australian Speed Championships (U/19) and the Australian Marathon Champs (U/19). She then finished third at the 2007 World Championship in May in the Formula 1 Division.{{cite web|url=http://www.iwsf.com/history/displayMedals.php?year=all&title=World+Championships&division=Ski+Racing |title=International Water Ski Federation IWSF Titles and Medal List |website=Iwsf.com |date= |accessdate=2016-02-04}} She retired shortly from racing after her father's death in 2008.{{cite web|url=http://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/news/sydney-news/eagle-wont-race-again/story-e6freuzi-1111115808204 |title=Eagle Won't Race Again |website=Dailytelegraph.com.au |accessdate=2016-02-04}} In 2009 Lauryn returned to racing placing third at the 2009 World Championships, and 7th in the 2011 World Championships after suffering a big fall in the third race. ==Professional boxing career== Turning professional in 2010, she went 2–0–1 with 1 knockout that year and in 2011 she would suffer two split decision losses. On 13 July 2012, she defeated Kiangsak Sithsaithong (then 9–0–0 4KO) by a 5th-round TKO to win the [[World Boxing Foundation]] women's [[super featherweight]] title, improving her record to 3–2–1 2 knockouts.[http://www.heraldsun.com.au/sport/boxing-mma/lauryn-eagle-lands-a-womens-world-title/story-fndn16fm-1226425813716 "Lauryn Eagle lands a women's world title"]. ''Herald Sun''. 13 July 2012. The match was widely criticised within the boxing media. Commentators pointed out that Eagle had not fought more than 6 rounds in her career, and had not won a fight since 2010.{{cite web|url=http://www.theroar.com.au/2012/05/15/boxings-absurd-celebrity-culture-continues-to-cause-damage/ |title=Lauryn Eagle to fight for world title as boxing's celebrity culture continues |publisher=The Roar |date=15 May 2012 |accessdate=23 July 2012}} It was also noted that Sithsaithong's record was almost entirely against debut fighters{{cite web|url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/sport/boxing-mma/title-fight-not-what-it-seems-for-boxing-stunner-lauryn-eagle/story-fndn16fm-1226423935674 |title=Title Fight Not What It Seems for Boxing Stunner Lauryn Eagle |website=Heraldsun.com.au |accessdate=2016-02-04}} in Thai villages.{{cite web|author=Adam Auld |url=http://www.aus-boxing.com/2012/07/13/susie-ramadan-lauryn-eagle-win-titles-over-thai-opponents/ |title=Susie Ramadan & Lauryn Eagle win titles over Thai opponents |publisher=Aus-Boxing |date=13 July 2012 |accessdate=23 July 2012}} In September 2012, she did a promotional fight against [[Fox FM (Melbourne)|Fox FM]] radio joc [[Matt Tilley]] in a 'Champ vs Chump' promotion.{{cite web|url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/news/eagle-eyes-her-opponent/story-fnbk7kwa-1226427524545 |title=Eagle Eyes Her Opponent |website=Heraldsun.com.au |accessdate=2016-02-04}} Eagle won the three round fight by a TKO in the third round.{{cite web|url=http://www.fox.com.au/shows/mattandjo/features/champ-vs-chump-2?selectedImage=23 |title=hit101.9 Fox FM | Melbourne's Number 1 Hit Music Station |website=Fox.com.au |date= |accessdate=2016-02-04}} Two days later Eagle fought [[New Zealand]]'s Nicki Bigwood winning in a unanimous decision in a six-round bout on as an undercard to former [[rugby league]] player [[Solomon Haumono]]'s fight.{{cite web|url=http://www.aus-boxing.com/2012/09/07/solomon-haumono-vs-franklin-egobi-live-results-blog/ |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130117155855/http://www.aus-boxing.com/2012/09/07/solomon-haumono-vs-franklin-egobi-live-results-blog/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=17 January 2013 |accessdate=10 September 2012 }} On January 30, 2013 she won the vacant [[List of Australian female boxing champions|Australia female lightweight title]] beating Nadine Brown on points at the [[Sydney Entertainment Centre]]. ==Modeling and media== Eagle also has a keen interest in modeling. In 2005, she competed in Miss Teen Australia in Darwin and won the title along with Miss Congeniality. She then went to Costa Rica in Central America and competed in [[Miss Teen International]] and made a clean sweep, winning Miss Teen International, along with Most Photogenic, Miss Congeniality and Best Silhouette.{{citation needed|date=May 2013}} In 2006, she won the [[FHM Australia|FHM]] Lara Croft Challenge involved physical challenges of shooting, running, ropes, ladders, 4-wheel driving and swimming.{{citation needed|date=May 2013}} She starred in the second season of [[The Celebrity Apprentice Australia (season 2)|the Celebrity Apprentice Australia]] where she lasted until the final episode where she finished fourth.{{citation needed|date=May 2013}} In the August edition of [[Maxim (Australia)|MAXIM magazine]], Eagle featured on the front cover and a photo shoot.[http://www.triplem.com.au/adelaide/funny-stuff/bad-medicine/blog/photo-lauryn-eagles-lingerie-front-cover-for-maxim-magazine/20120718-gr8h.html "Lauryn Eagles lingerie front cover for maxim magazine"]. Triplem.com.au. 18 July 2012. ==Personal life== In March 2008, Eagle's father Peter, a 10-time Australian water-skiing champion, died when his speedboat flipped and crashed.{{cite news|last=Duff|first=Eamonn|title=Tragedy haunts family|url=http://www.smh.com.au/articles/2008/03/08/1204780125755.html|accessdate=20 May 2013|newspaper=The Sydney Morning Herald|date=9 March 2008|author2=Walker, Frank|author3=Gilmore, Heath}} On 19 May 2013, Eagle was arrested at Northies [[Cronulla]] Hotel and charged with failing to leave premises when requested.{{cite news|last=Partridge|first=Emma|title=Lauryn Eagle arrested after refusing to leave hotel: police|url=http://www.smh.com.au/sport/boxing/lauryn-eagle-arrested-after-refusing-to-leave-hotel-police-20130520-2jw8m.html|accessdate=20 May 2013|newspaper=The Sydney Morning Herald|date=20 May 2013}} She had recently split with her boyfriend, rugby league player [[Todd Carney]].{{cite news|last=Reines|first=Ros|title=Todd Carney and Lauryn Eagle break-up|url=http://www.news.com.au/entertainment/celebrity/todd-carney-and-lauryn-eagle-break-up/story-fn907478-1226614412651|accessdate=20 May 2013|newspaper=news.com.au|date=8 April 2013}} On 9 January 2014, she was ordered by the courts to leave her Mother alone after a dispute over a family dog.{{cite web|url=http://news.ninemsn.com.au/national/2014/01/09/18/28/lauryn-eagle-ordered-to-stay-away-from-mother |title=Lauryn Eagle ordered to stay away from mother - 9news.com.au |website=News.ninemsn.com.au |date= |accessdate=2016-02-04}} On January 30, 2018 she was convicted of drug driving, fined $600 and banned from driving for six months. The magistrate rejected an application to record no conviction, noting her poor traffic record.{{cite web|url=http://www.smh.com.au/nsw/boxer-lauryn-eagle-convicted-of-drugdriving-20180130-h0qdp4.html |title=Boxer Lauryn Eagle convicted of drug-driving |website=www.smh.com.au |date= |accessdate=2018-01-30}} ==Professional boxing record== {{BoxingRecordSummary |draws = 1 |nc= |ko-wins = 10 |ko-losses = |dec-wins = 8 |dec-losses = 4 |dq-wins = |dq-losses = }} {|class="wikitable" style="text-align:center; font-size:95%" |- !{{abbr|No.|Number}} !Result !Record !Opponent !Type !Round, time {{Infobox venue | stadium_name = Monte Carlo Country Club | nickname = | image = [[Image:Terrains Monte-Carlo Rolex Masters 1000.JPG|220px]] | fullname = | location = [[Roquebrune-Cap-Martin]], France | coordinates = {{coord|43.751667|7.440728|display=it|type:landmark}} | broke_ground = | built = | opened = 1928 | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = | operator = | surface = clay | construction_cost = | architect = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | project_manager = | main_contractors = | former_names = | tenants = [[Monte-Carlo Masters]] ([[ Association of Tennis Professionals|Tennis]]) (present) | seating_capacity = 9,000 ([[Tennis]]) | dimensions = | scoreboard = }} '''Monte Carlo Country Club (MCCC)''' is the home of the [[Association of Tennis Professionals|ATP]]'s [[Monte Carlo Masters]] tournament. It is also the base of the Monte Carlo Tennis Academy.
Despite the club's name, it is not located in [[Monte Carlo]] or even in [[Monaco]]; it is actually located in the commune of [[Roquebrune-Cap-Martin]] in the [[Alpes-Maritimes]] department of France, just outside Monaco's northeastern border.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://montecarlo.masters-series.com/4/fr/event/GuideAccess.jpg |title=Itinéraires d'acèss au Masters Series Monte-Carlo |publisher=Monte Carlo Masters |format=[[JPEG]] |language=French |accessdate=2008-02-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080229035342/http://montecarlo.masters-series.com/4/fr/event/GuideAccess.jpg |archivedate=2008-02-29 |df= }}</ref>

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2011}} {{Use Australian English|date=June 2011}} {{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Motordrome | nickname = | image = | location = [[Melbourne & Olympic Parks|Olympic Park]], Batman Avenue, [[Melbourne]], [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]] | coordinates = {{Coord|37|49|29|S|144|58|52|E|type:landmark_scale:2000|display=it}} | broke_ground = | opened = 1924 | closed = 1951 | demolished = 1951 | owner = Melbourne Carnivals Pty Ltd | operator = | surface = Grass (oval)/Concrete (raceway) | construction_cost = | architect = | tenants = | former_names = Olympic Park Speedway, Melbourne Speedway, Victorian Speedway | seating_capacity = 15 000 for football, 32 000 for racing. |}}
The '''Motordrome''', also known as the '''Olympic Park Speedway''', the '''Melbourne Speedway''' or the '''Victorian Speedway''', was a former [[Dirt track racing|speedway]] and [[Australian rules football]] ground located on the site of [[Melbourne Sports and Entertainment Precinct#Olympic Park|Olympic Park]] in [[Melbourne]], [[Victoria, Australia|Victoria]]. The ground was primarily a speedway track, but also hosted football matches.
==History== Melbourne Carnivals Pty. Ltd, a company established in 1923 by Jack Campbell and Jim DuFrocq, developed and leased a large site known as the '''Amateur Sports Ground''' from the Crown with the help of local entrepreneur [[John Wren]].<ref name="Walker">{{cite book|last1=Walker|first1=Terry|title=Fast Tracks - Australia's Motor Racing Circuits 1904-1995|date=1995|publisher=Turton & Armstrong|location=Sydney|isbn=0908031556|pages=114}}</ref> On the site, the Motordrome was constructed. The stadium contained a grassed oval suitable for football, set inside a saucer-shaped concrete oval track suitable for motor racing;<ref name="Argus23Sep" /> the track was a third of a mile long and banked at a 46° angle.<ref>{{cite news|newspaper=Townsville Daily Bulletin (Supplement)|publication-place=Townsville, QLD|date=6 December 1924|page=5|title=New Speedway}}</ref> Although Melbourne Carnivals originally had visions for the stadium to accommodate 100,000 spectators,<ref name="Argus23Sep">{{cite news|newspaper=The Argus|publication-place=Melbourne, VIC|title=Football – the Tenth Club|page=10|date=23 September 1924|author=Old Boy}}</ref> it was ultimately built to accommodate around 32,000. The Motordrome was opened on 29 November 1924, and 32,000 spectators attended the inaugural race meeting.<ref name="opening">{{cite news|newspaper=The Australasian|publication-place=Melbourne, VIC|title=Racing summary|date=6 December 1924|page=1341}}</ref>
In 1933, the ageing concrete surface of the motor racing track was no longer suitable for the higher powered vehicles which used it, so it was demolished and replaced with a [[Race track#Surfaces|dirt track]] which continued to be used for motor racing.<ref name="Walker" /> In the same year, the Amateur Sports Ground was renamed '''Olympic Park''', and the name was generally used for both the former Motordrome stadium, and the wider park in which it was situated. The name change had no connection to the [[Olympic Games]] – Melbourne was not selected as the host of the [[1956 Summer Olympics]] until 1949 – and rather was chosen because the former name 'Amateur Sports Ground' no longer reflected the class and type of sport which was now played on the grounds.<ref>{{cite news|newspaper=The Argus|publication-place=Melbourne, VIC|date=6 April 1933|page=9|title=Motordrome obsolete}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|newspaper=The Argus|publication-place=Melbourne, VIC|date=11 May 1933|page=13|title=Changes at Motordrome}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|newspaper=The Argus|publication-place=Melbourne, VIC|date=24 June 1933|page=21|title=Amateur Sports Ground}}</ref>
The complex was sold after the Second World War and began to be converted into the [[Olympic Park Stadium]] used during the [[1956 Summer Olympics|1956 Olympics]].<ref name="Walker" />
===Motor racing=== During the time of the [[Great Depression]] the ground regularly drew in crowds of more than 30,000 to watch speedway, [[Motorcycle speedway|motorcycle]] and [[Sidecar speedway|sidecar]] racing. It is generally acknowledged that the first [[Midget car racing|Speedcar]] race in Australia took place at the speedway in 1934.
In 1936/37, the speedway also saw two [[Motorcycle speedway]] test matches between the [[Australia national speedway team|Australians]], including future ([[1938 Individual Speedway World Championship|1938]]) [[Speedway World Championship|Speedway World Champion]] [[Bluey Wilkinson]], taking on the visiting [[United States national speedway team|Americans]] who included the [[1937 Individual Speedway World Championship|1937]] World Champion [[Jack Milne]] and his younger brother [[Cordy Milne|Cordy]], as well as [[Wilbur Lamoreaux]] who would finish second behind Milne in the 1937 World Final at the [[Wembley Stadium (1923)|Empire Stadium]] in [[London]] (Cordy Milne would finish third). Australia won the first test 31-23 on 19 December 1936, and won the third test 30-24 on 23 January 1937 (the second test, won 29-24 by Australia, was held at the [[Sydney Showground Speedway|Sydney Showground]] on 28 December).
===Football=== Although not much top-level football was played on the Motordrome, its presence as a high capacity centrally-located ground had a significant off-field impact on football during the 1920s and 1930s.
When the venue was first established in 1924, the [[Australian Football League|Victorian Football League]] was very keen for strategic reasons to control it. Melbourne Carnivals had offered to lease the ground to the new [[Public Service Football Club]] if it were admitted to the League in 1925. This offer became the trigger for off-field negotiations which ultimately saw {{AFL Foo}}, {{AFL Haw}} and {{AFL Nor}} [[1925 VFL season#Expansion of the VFL|admitted to the VFL]], but saw the VFL fail to secure the use of the Motordrome. There had been proposals for the [[Richmond Football Club]] to move to the venue, or for it to be used as a neutral venue to which each club moved one or two of its home matches each year; however, these proposals fell through.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.aamipark.com.au/ResourceImage.aspx?raid=853 | format=pdf | title=Football Control The Motordrome Bait / Proposal for the League | date=25 February 1925 | publisher=The Argus | accessdate=26 June 2011 }}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> The [[Victorian Football League|Victorian Football Association]] went on to play its finals matches at the venue in 1925, 1926 and 1927.
Prior to the 1931 season, the VFL and the Grounds Management Association (which represented the operators of most of the VFL grounds) entered a dispute over the use of the grounds for football matches, covering financial arrangements and the demarcation between the football and cricket seasons.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article183012634 |title=Football on Motordrome V.F.L. Has Option Over Three Other Arenas. |newspaper=[[The Sporting Globe]] |location=Melbourne, Vic. |date=31 January 1931 |accessdate=5 February 2016 |page=4 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref> During the dispute, the VFL arranged for the Motordrome, as well as the [[Carlton Gardens|Exhibition Oval]], to host twelve games which were to be transferred away from the grounds involved in the dispute,<ref>{{cite news|newspaper=The Sporting Globe|publication-place=Melbourne, VIC|title=League arranges fixtures|author=W. S. Sharland|page=4|date=14 March 1931}}</ref> but the dispute was ultimately resolved through arbitration in March and the games were transferred back to their original grounds.<ref>{{cite news|newspaper=Referee|publication-place=Sydney, NSW|title=Victorian grounds trouble settled|author=Southerner|page=11|date=25 March 1931}}</ref>
Then in 1932, the VFA signed a deal to use the Motordrome as a neutral central venue from 1933 until 1940. Under the agreement, the VFA would play one match at the ground each weekend during the season, with each club moving one or two of its home games to the ground each year, as well as playing the finals there. This caused a [[1934 VFA season#Central ground dispute|massive dispute]] with the local councils which owned the VFA's suburban grounds, and it culminated in seven of the VFA's twelve clubs being kicked out of their local grounds until the agreement was rescinded, almost ruining the 1934 VFA season and potentially forcing those clubs to disband or secede ''en masse'' from the VFA. The agreement was rescinded shortly before the season began.<ref name="resolution">{{cite news|newspaper=The Argus|publication-place=Melbourne, VIC|date=27 March 1934|page=8|title=Grounds dispute ended}}</ref><ref name="Argus27March">{{cite news|newspaper=The Argus|publication-place=Melbourne, VIC|date=27 March 1934|page=8|title=Grounds management – secession suggestions}}</ref>
The [[Richmond Football Club]] formally announced its intentions to move its home base from the [[Punt Road Oval]] to Olympic Park prior to the 1936 season, owing mostly to an ongoing dispute with the [[Monash Tigers|Richmond Cricket Club]]. Richmond's proposal to move was ultimately voted down by the VFL, but only by the [[casting vote]] of League president [[William C. McClelland|William McClelland]].<ref>{{cite news|newspaper=The Argus|publication-place=Melbourne, VIC|date=24 February 1936|page=7|title=Richmond to remain - Football League decides}}</ref>
The only VFL premiership football ever played at the venue occurred during the early part of [[1932 VFL season|1932]], when {{AFL Mel}} played three home matches there because the [[Melbourne Cricket Ground]] was being resurfaced.
In the 1935 pre-season, the venue staged a night match under electric floodlights between 1934 VFL Grand Finalists {{AFL Ric}} and {{AFL SM}}. The players had some visibility problems, mostly with depth perception, but the match attracted 25,000 spectators.<ref>{{cite news|newspaper=The Argus|publication-place=Melbourne, VIC|date=1 April 1935|page=7|title=Under floodlights – football experiment}}</ref> Further exhibition night matches were played at the end of 1935 between VFA Grand Finalists [[Yarraville Football Club|Yarraville]] and [[Camberwell Football Club|Camberwell]],<ref>{{cite news|newspaper=The Argus|publication-place=Melbourne, VIC|date=27 September 1935|page=12|title=Night match – Innovation unpopular}}</ref> and at the end of 1936 between combined teams representing the VFL and VFA.<ref>{{cite news|newspaper=The Argus|publication-place=Melbourne, VIC|date=25 September 1936|page=15|title=Night game – win for League}}</ref>
School and junior football was regularly played on the venue.
===Other=== On 11 December 1926, the venue hosted a shambolic [[Ostrich#racing|ostrich racing]] event. A full program of races was scheduled, but the event was cancelled after three farcical attempts at races – in which startled ostriches ridden by inanimate jockeys ran in opposite directions, and ostriches attached to [[sulky|sulkies]] failed to break out of a walk.<ref>{{cite news|newspaper=The Argus|title=Ostrich racing – a complete fiasco|page=19|date=13 December 1926|publication-place=Melbourne, VIC}}</ref>

'''[[Mozambique]]''' competed in the [[Olympic Games]] for the first time at the '''[[1980 Summer Olympics]]''' in [[Moscow]], [[Soviet Union|USSR]].
==Results by event== ===[[Athletics at the 1980 Summer Olympics|Athletics]]=== '''Men's 100 metres''' * [[Eduardo Costa (athlete)|Eduardo Costa]] :* Heat — 11.02 (→ did not advance)
'''Men's 200 metres''' * [[Constantino Reis]] :* Heat — did not start (→ did not advance)
'''Men's 1,500 metres''' *[[Vicente Santos]] :* Heat — 3:58.7 (→ did not advance)
'''Men's 5,000 metres''' *[[Pedro Mulomo]] :* Heat — 15:11.9 (→ did not advance)
'''Men's 10,000 metres''' *[[Dias Alface]] :* Heat — did not finish (→ did not advance)
'''Men's 110 m Hurdles''' * [[Abdul Ismail (hurdler)|Abdul Ismail]] :* Heat — 15.18 (→ did not advance)
'''Men's Long Jump''' * [[Stelio Craveirinha]] :* Qualification — 6.94 m (→ did not advance)
'''Women's 800 metres''' * [[Acacia Mate]] :* Heat — 2:19.7 (→ did not advance)
'''Women's Discus Throw''' * [[Oliveira Ludovina]] :* Qualification — no mark (→ did not advance)
===[[Swimming at the 1980 Summer Olympics|Swimming]]=== '''Men's 100 metre freestyle''' * [[Edgar Martins (swimmer)|Edgar Martins]] :* Heats – 1:06.17 (→ did not advance, 39th place)
'''Men's 200 metre freestyle''' * [[Ntewane Machel]] :* Heats – 2:35.45 (→ did not advance, 37th place)

revision.comment: +[[Category:Sports venues completed in 2012]]; +[[Category:2012 establishments in Florida]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
{{Infobox stadium | name = Nations Park | nickname = | logo_image = Nations_Park_Logo.png | logo_size = 220px | logo_caption = ''Logo of Nations Park'' | fullname = | former_names = | location=[[Newberry, Florida|Newberry]], Florida, US | coordinates = {{Coord|29.620679|N|82.599463|W|type:landmark_region:US-FL|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = 2011 | built = 2011/2012 | opened = June 30, 2012 | renovated = | expanded = | owner = | operator = | surface = | scoreboard = | cost = | architect = | project_manager = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | main_contractors = | capacity = | suites = | record_attendance = | dimensions = | acreage = | volume = | tenants = | embedded = | website = {{URL|nationspark.com}} }}
'''Nations Park''' is an open invitational baseball tournament complex located in the city of [[Newberry, Florida|Newberry]], Florida opening in the summer of 2012. The park was formed with partnerships between the City of Newberry, Nations Baseball Florida Inc., and the Alachua County Tourism Development Board.<ref>Marlowe, Jordan (2011). 'Nations Park'. http://jordanmarlowe.com/issues/nations-park/.</ref> The facility has 16 stadiums.
==History== Lou Presutti, founder of Cooperstown Dreams Park came to the City of Newberry in 2009 to establish the park. It completed construction in 2012, but the grand opening was delayed until March 2013.
[[File:Nations Park sign.jpg|thumb|right|<center>Nations Park Sign</center>]]
Nations Park is a $7 million baseball tournament complex that is built on 40 acres of land donated by the Davis family on the corner of US 41/27 and SW 30th Ave.<ref>Curry, Christopher (2011). 'Baseball complex spurs big dreams for Newberry'. Gainesville Sun. http://www.gainesville.com/article/20110726/ARTICLES/110729618</ref><ref>Marlowe, Jordan (2011). 'Nations Park'. http://jordanmarlowe.com/issues/nations-park/.</ref> In July 2011, the construction of Nations Park came to a brief stop upon discovery of several endangered Gopher Tortoises. The construction remained on hold for several weeks while experts were brought on site to relocate the protected species to a tortoise sanctuary.<ref>Curry, Christopher (2011). 'Gopher tortoises delay Newberry baseball park construction'. Gainesville Sun. http://www.gainesville.com/article/20110726/ARTICLES/110729618</ref> The 16 fields for Nations Park are completed as of April, 2012 and are ready to play for the inaugural 2012 tournaments.<ref>Curry, Christopher (2011). 'Newberry baseball complex taking shape'. Gainesville Sun. http://www.gainesville.com/article/20111127/ARTICLES/111129623?p=1&tc=pg</ref><ref>Harvard, Melissa (2011). Nations Park to open this summer'. Gainesville Sun. http://www.alachuacountytoday.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=2180:nations-park-to-open-this-summer&catid=102:local&Itemid=426</ref>
[[File:Nations Park Field 1.jpg|thumb|left|<center> Nations Park Field</center>]]
==Stadiums== The 16 stadiums at Nations Park are built for multiple age groups, 8- to 14-year-old baseball players and 12- to 14-year-old girls fastpitch softball players. The stadiums are fully enclosed and have natural grass outfields and synthetic turf infields. In each stadium, the mounds and basepaths are all adjustable to accompany the correct age group and boasts 220' foot walls and a scorer's tower.
[[File:Nations Park Field 2.jpg|thumb|right|<center>Backdrop of Nations Park Field</center>]]
==Tournaments== Nations Park will host week-long summer and holiday tournaments for American and Canadian boys' baseball and girls' fastpitch softball teams.>
[[File:Nations Park Home plate.jpg|thumb|right|<center>Nations Park Home Plate</center>]]
===Tournament Schedule, Summer 2012=== * June 30- July 5 (13U) * July 7–12 (13U) * July 28- August 2 (12U)
==Economic Impact== The park was expected to have huge economical impact on the small city of Newberry. Nations Park is projected to attract between 90,000 and 120,000 people to Newberry each summer. Once completed, the park may pump an estimated $20 million into the local economy.<ref>Lovette, Corrie (2011). 'Newberry's Nations Park wants "Wow Factor"'. WCJB. http://www.wcjb.com/local-news/2011/06/newberrys-nations-park-wants-wow-factor</ref><ref>Lovette, Corrie (2011). 'Enhancements for Newberry's "Nations Park" '. WCJB. http://www.wcjb.com/local-news/2011/06/enhancements-newberrys-nations-park</ref> The park will help generate an additional 50,000 to 80,000 local room nights per year that will supplement the city's tourism revenue.<ref>Curry, Christopher (2011). 'Baseball complex spurs big dreams for Newberry'. Gainesville Sun. http://www.gainesville.com/article/20110726/ARTICLES/110729618</ref>
==Expansion== There are plans in the future to expand Nations Park to 32 fields. The city of Newberry, Nations Baseball Florida Inc., and the Alachua County Tourism Development Board will have to gain more tourism revenue needed for an expansion.<ref>Curry, Christopher (2011). 'Baseball complex spurs big dreams for Newberry'. Gainesville Sun. http://www.gainesville.com/article/20110726/ARTICLES/110729618</ref><ref>Marlowe, Jordan (2011). 'Nations Park'. http://jordanmarlowe.com/issues/nations-park/.</ref>
==External links== * [http://nationspark.com/ Official website]
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Buildings and structures in Alachua County, Florida]] [[Category:Baseball venues in Florida]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2012]] [[Category:2012 establishments in Florida]]

revision.comment: Adress Modfication
revision.text:
[[Image:Painstation.jpg|right|thumb|250px|Painstation at the Games Convention 2006]] '''PainStation''' is a [[torture device]] created by the artists' group <!-- Yes, it really is spelled this way -->"/////////fur//// art entertainment interfaces". <ref name="wired">{{cite news|url=https://www.wired.com/news/games/0,2101,50875,00.html |title=No Pain, No Game |publisher=Wired News (link via archive.org) |date=March 7, 2002 |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20030207171752/http://www.wired.com/news/games/0,2101,50875,00.html |archivedate=February 7, 2003 }}</ref>
==History== <!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image:Never Say Never Againdomination.jpg|thumb|right|270px|Bond playing Largo in the game "Domination" as Domino Petachi looks on.]] -->The system was originally developed by Tilman Reiff and Volker Morawe, two students at the ''Kunsthochschule für Medien Köln'' ([[Academy of Media Arts Cologne]]) in 2001, as an interactive art object. The pair later enhanced the device and released it under the company name of the "//////////fur//// art entertainment interfaces".<ref>See [http://www.khm.de/~morawe/painstation/PainStation_ger.pdf Painstation-Neuzeitliches Duellierungs Artefakt (Painstation - Modern Duelling artifact)] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928103548/http://www.khm.de/~morawe/painstation/PainStation_ger.pdf |date=2007-09-28 }}</ref> The designers were inspired by the children's game Folter-Mau-Mau<ref>On the Media, June 27, 2003, Transcript and interview as .mp3 at [http://www.onthemedia.org/yore/transcripts/transcripts_062703_painstation.html They Like Pain(Station)] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110622073302/http://www.onthemedia.org/yore/transcripts/transcripts_062703_painstation.html |date=June 22, 2011 }}</ref> and the development of the modern computer game.
A similar game concept was featured in the 1983 James Bond movie ''[[Never Say Never Again]]''.
The original concept was followed up with other stages of development which were regularly exhibited worldwide in different cultural contexts.
Following talks with [[Sony]], the artists described the Painstation as "The artwork formerly known as Painstation".
==Structure== While the underlying artistic concept remained consistent over the years, the group continues to improve on the system.
==Basic Concept== The Painstation consists of a specially made case which gives two players the opportunity of playing a specially adapted and expanded variant of the classic video game, Pong, against each other. The electronic controls are connected by digital transducers to several components providing sensory feedback to players.
During the game, the players place their left hands on the PEU (Pain Execution Unit) which serves as a sensor and feedback instrument. Possible feedback effects are heat impulses, an electric shock and an integrated miniature wire whip. The feedback generated is dependent on the playing process and can increase in its intensity. The respective opponent can try to alter his or her playing style to purposely change the intensity of the feedback.
The following bonus items can be activated by hits in the current version of the software in 2006:
*Increase Ball Speed (3 levels) *Double Pain Execution Time *Quadruple Pain Execution Time *Almost Unblockable Ricochet *Cut Height of Bar By 50% *Deadly Row *Electric Boogaloo *Burn In Bright *Death Penalty *Cheese! *Ease the Pain! *Cluster Bomb
No matter the score, the first player to remove his or her hand from the PEU device loses the game.<ref>Sample video (QuickTime) at [http://www.khm.de/%7Emorawe/painstation/ps_movie_hi.html Painstation - Do you feel the pain?] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061129185810/http://www.khm.de/%7Emorawe/painstation/ps_movie_hi.html |date=2006-11-29 }}</ref>
==Painstation== The heart of the original system was the [[Apple Computer]] G3 Macintosh, as well as a specifically made control plate. The programming was done with Macromedia Director and [[C++]].The model was developed predominately out of available junk using a tube monitor. The first five high scores were originally computer generated absurdly high as a deterrent, but one entry was actually overwritten by a player at the [[Games Convention]] in 2006. Since then, "GOL" is on the list in second place with 300 points.
==Painstation 2.0== Starting in 2002, the successor of the original Painstation was developed, the Painstation 2.0.
Apart from adjustable pain levels, it offers several replaceable whips and an additional source of light which players can use to produce glare on their opponent's side of the screen. The program was reprogrammed under [[Microsoft Windows|Windows]] and the application was implemented in C++ and [[OpenGL]], because the hardware the previous version had been based on became obsolete. The PEUs were fabricated for the first time with [[laser]]s from stainless [[steel]]. The higher processor performance makes it possible for the system to control the speed of the whip engine and the strength of the electric current individually.
The system was also for the first time made coin-operated. It is equipped with a 15 inch [[LCD monitor]] and it was shown to the public on June 25, 2003 on the German Harald Schmidt television show.<ref>See ''Even more enhanced duelling artefact'', online at [http://www.fursr.com/details.php?id=51&pid=51 PainStation 2.0] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927011306/http://www.fursr.com/details.php?id=51&pid=51 |date=2007-09-27 }}</ref><ref>[http://www.painstation.de/new/collection.html The Collection] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071227071156/http://www.painstation.de/new/collection.html |date=2007-12-27 }} (Description of all models with further hints)</ref>
==Painstation 2.5== The new case, painted in three metallic colors, consists mostly of medium density wood fiber panels and has a modular design. This makes it easier to transport the system and to exchange defective components. Besides a 15 inch color screen, there is standard PC technology inside and a special control plate. The pain levels can be changed from 50% to 150%. The player must confirm that they are willing to participate in the game by pressing a "I agree" button before playing. Added benefits for the players include leather padded arm rests and the new [[ergonomic]] layout of the controls. Newly added fans in the PEUs cool the system down better between games to avoid electronic problems and can serve the players if they hit the right bonus item.{{citation needed|reason=Where did this information come from; there's no source cited|date=December 2015}}
==Exhibitions==
* [[Computerspielemuseum Berlin]], since 2011 - The PainStation is part of the permanent exhibition. Playable during the opening hours of the museum for visitors of the age of 18 or older.
The system has been publicly presented at the following exhibitions and fairs: * ''Schmerz'' Exhibit in [[Berlin]] 2007 *''pong.mythos'' in the Museum for Communication in [[Frankfurt/Main]] from November 16, 2006 - January 21, 2007<ref>[http://www.pong-mythos.net/ pong.mythos]</ref> *''Emergences 2006'', Maison de la Villette, [[Paris]], from September 29, 2006 - October 1, 2006 *''GamesConvention'', [[Leipzig]], 2006 *''Electrical Fantasista Exhibition'', BankART NYK, [[Yokohama]], from February 24, 2006 - March 16, 2006<ref>See ''Battle against ESD'', [http://blog.fursr.com/?pg=2 http://blog.fursr.com] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927011241/http://blog.fursr.com/?pg=2 |date=2007-09-27 }}</ref> *''Blind Spots'', Hannah Maclure Centre, [[Dundee]], from January 30, 2006 - May 19, 2006 *''[[St. Gallen Symposium|ISC Symposium]]'', [[University of St. Gallen|University of St.Gallen]], [[Switzerland]], 2004 *''Venus im Pelz'' (Venus in Furs), Neue Galerie, [[Graz]], 2003 *''DEAF 03'', Parkhuis, [[Rotterdam]], 2003 *''Cyberarts Exhibition'', OK Center, [[Linz]], 2002 *''Altitude 2001'', [[Cologne]], July 20, 2001 * ''Technisches Museum'', [[Vienna]] * ''HNF Heinz-Nixdorf-Forum'', [[Paderborn]] <ref>[http://www.hnf.de/start.html/ Heinz Nixdorf Forum Paderborn]</ref>
In the past years, the system has also been repeatedly displayed in clubs and discothèques, at LAN parties and at BDSM parties.
==Awards== * International Media Art Award, SWR/ZKM 2003 * [[Prix Ars Electronica]] 2002, "Anerkennung/Interaktive Kunst" (Acknowledgement/Interactive Art)
==See also== *[[Shocking Duel]] *[[Pong]]
==References== {{reflist}} {{refbegin}} {{refend}}
==External links== * [http://www.painstation.de Painstation information page] Official site * [http://www.g4tv.com/techvvault/features/37439/Painstation_Gaming_Till_It_Hurts.html Painstation_Gaming_Till_It_Hurts] [[G4 (U.S. TV channel)|G4]], Tech Live, April 22, 2002 * [https://www.wired.com/news/games/0,2101,50875,00.html No Pain, No Game] [[Wired.com]], March 7, 2002 * [http://www.fursr.com/ Blog of the artists] <!-- This link is dead and an active replacement could not be found *http://www.wpr.org/book/020414B.htm/ Wisconsin Public Radio, Video Games: from Pong to Painstation --> * [http://www.heise.de/tp/r4/html/result.xhtml?url=/tp/r4/artikel/12/12058/1.html&words=Painstation/ Leiden und leiden lassen] Telepolis, March 12, 2002 * [http://www.destructoid.com/destructoid-interview-the-diabolical-tilman-reiff-co-creator-of-painstation-46246.phtml/ The Diabolical Tilman Reiff Co-Creator of Painstation] Destructoid.com

/* Return to natural grass */ Not really necessary.
revision.text:
'''Poly-Turf''' was a brand of [[artificial turf]] in the early 1970s, manufactured by American Biltrite of [[Wellesley, Massachusetts]]. It was the first specifically designed for [[American football]], with a patented layered structure which included a "shock pad" between the [[artificial grass]] and the asphalt sub-surface.<ref>U.S. Patent number 3661687, inventors Arthur F. Spinney and Lawrence J. Warnalis</ref> It used [[polypropylene]] for its artificial grass blades, rather than the [[nylon]] used in [[AstroTurf]] and [[3M]]'s Tartan Turf.<ref name=sltmsd>{{cite magazine |url=https://www.si.com/vault/1971/11/15/613905/new-slant-on-the-mod-sod |magazine=Sports Illustrated |title=New Slant on the Mod Sod |last=Underwood |first=John |date=November 15, 1971 |page=32|accessdate=October 29, 2014}}</ref><ref name=mdsdrev>{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=LP4cAAAAIBAJ&sjid=HJwEAAAAIBAJ&pg=2850%2C5620745 |newspaper=Tuscaloosa News |agency=Associated Press |title=Mod-sod revolution felt |date=June 30, 1970 |page=8 }}</ref><ref name=tyofphfl>{{cite magazine |url=https://www.si.com/vault/1985/08/12/620600/the-tyranny-of-phony-fields |magazine=Sports Illustrated |last=Johnson |first=William Oscar |title=The tyranny of phony fields |date=August 12, 1985 |page=34|accessdate=October 29, 2014 }}</ref>
==History in Miami== In the late 1960s, the natural grass surface at the [[Miami Orange Bowl|Orange Bowl]] in [[Miami]] was commonly in poor condition,<ref name=jcobonbch>{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=lJ4yAAAAIBAJ&sjid=yOkFAAAAIBAJ&pg=2506%2C188655 |newspaper=Miami News |last=Crittenden |first=John |title=Orange Bowl's on the beach |date=October 16, 1968 |page=1D }}</ref> primarily due to heavy usage; 34 games were scheduled there during the 1968 football season.<ref name=torturetst>{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=HJ8yAAAAIBAJ&sjid=2-kFAAAAIBAJ&pg=2237%2C408784 |newspaper=Miami News |last=Plaisted |first=Ed |title=Orange Bowl grass faces torture test |date=August 1, 1968 |page=3D }}</ref>
Poly-Turf was installed at the city-owned stadium in [[1970 Miami Dolphins season|1970]],<ref name=owdlptrf>{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=Y5JGAAAAIBAJ&sjid=TS8NAAAAIBAJ&pg=6034%2C5886811 |newspaper=Palm Beach Post-Times |last=Petrella |first=Tony |title=Owners dislike Poly-Turf |date=August 30, 1970 |page=D4 }}</ref> and utilized for six seasons. The stadium was used for both [[College football|college]] and [[Professional football (gridiron)|professional]] football, primarily by the [[Miami Hurricanes football|University of Miami Hurricanes]] and the [[Miami Dolphins]] of the [[National Football League|NFL]]. It also hosted the eponymous New Year's Day college [[Orange Bowl|bowl game]], [[Super Bowl]] games, and [[high school football]].
The [[Nebraska Cornhuskers football|University of Nebraska Cornhuskers]] won the first three Orange Bowl games played on Poly-Turf, which included two national championships. The first Super Bowl played on artificial turf was played on Poly-Turf in the Orange Bowl in January 1971, when the [[1970 Baltimore Colts season|Baltimore Colts]] defeated the [[1970 Dallas Cowboys season|Dallas Cowboys]] 16-13 in [[Super Bowl V]]. The next Super Bowl at the stadium was the final game played on Poly-Turf in Miami; [[Super Bowl X]] in January 1976.<ref name=ibtgraob>{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=0MMeAAAAIBAJ&sjid=k8oEAAAAIBAJ&pg=2578%2C150408 |newspaper=Daytona Beach Morning Journal |agency=Associated Press |title=It's back to grass for Orange Bowl after Sunday's game |date=January 16, 1976 |page=6B }}</ref> Its flaws received additional media exposure the week prior to the game,<ref name=lmrep>{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=TBgjAAAAIBAJ&sjid=980FAAAAIBAJ&pg=2219%2C6637243 |newspaper=Palm Beach Post-Times |title=Last-minute repairs |agency=photo |date=January 17, 1976 |page=D1}}</ref> and Dolphins receiver [[Nat Moore]] documented them in a local article.<ref name=dearsirs>{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=ShgjAAAAIBAJ&sjid=980FAAAAIBAJ&pg=2864%2C5754757 |newspaper=Palm Beach Post |last=Moore |first=Nat |authorlink=Nat Moore |title=Dear Sirs: |date=January 15, 1976 |page=D1 }}</ref>
The longer polypropylene blades of Poly-Turf tended to mat down<ref name=rugsi>{{cite magazine |url=https://www.si.com/vault/1971/10/18/612477/scorecard |magazine=Sports Illustrated |title=Scorecard: Rug |date=October 18, 1971 |accessdate=October 29, 2014}}</ref><ref name=lmtlydn>{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=CqFWAAAAIBAJ&sjid=3ecDAAAAIBAJ&pg=3803%2C4433894 |newspaper=Eugene Register-Guard |title=Lazy Miami artificial turf still laying down on job |date=October 20, 1971 |page=3D}}</ref> and become very slick under hot & sunny conditions.<ref name=haptf>{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=LooyAAAAIBAJ&sjid=YrYFAAAAIBAJ&pg=5336%2C2136576 |newspaper=Palm Beach Post |last=Petrella |first=Tony |title=Poly-Turf: a headache |date=October 5, 1971 |page=D1 }}</ref><ref name=trbques>{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=VEUyAAAAIBAJ&sjid=XbYFAAAAIBAJ&pg=823%2C1648461|newspaper=Palm Beach Post |last=Petrella |first=Tony |title=Orange Bowl's Poly-Turf: troubles and questions |date=October 19, 1971 |page=B5 }}</ref><ref name=ptdnorup>{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=V0UyAAAAIBAJ&sjid=XbYFAAAAIBAJ&pg=6261%2C3370917 |newspaper=Palm Beach Post |agency=wire services |title=Poly-Turf...down or up? |date=October 22, 1971 |page=H1 }}</ref> Other NFL owners were skeptical of the brand before the first regular season games were played in 1970.<ref name=owdlptrf/> The field was replaced after two seasons,<ref name=btrtorecob>{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=OnkyAAAAIBAJ&sjid=HbcFAAAAIBAJ&pg=777%2C1926259 |newspaper=Palm Beach Post |title=Biltrite to re-carpet Orange Bowl |date=January 22, 1972 |page=C4 }}</ref><ref name=obtrbtgr>{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=h3QtAAAAIBAJ&sjid=GJcFAAAAIBAJ&pg=7023%2C5103698 |newspaper=Palm Beach Daily News |agency=UPI |title= Orange Bowl to receive better 'grass' |date=January 23, 1972 |page=18 }}</ref> before the Dolphins' [[1972 Miami Dolphins season|1972]] undefeated season.<ref>[http://www.sun-sentinel.com/topic/sports/football/miami-orange-bowl--PLTRA0000003.topic Sun-Sentinel.com] – Miami Orange Bowl – 2008</ref> It was replaced by another Poly-Turf surface. While it had similar problems,<ref name=stfinfur>{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=0dYzAAAAIBAJ&sjid=LOsFAAAAIBAJ&pg=5414%2C1876876 |newspaper=Miami News |last=Nobles |first=Charlie |title=Slippery turf infuriates Hurricanes |date=September 6, 1972 |page=1D }}</ref><ref name=slibsubj>{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=roQyAAAAIBAJ&sjid=yLcFAAAAIBAJ&pg=1955%2C4419926 |newspaper=Palm Beach Post |last=Treglown |first=Dick |title=Orange Bowl turf: a slippery subject |date=September 26, 1972 |page=C1 }}</ref> it lasted longer than the first installation, and was used for four years. Over just six years, both installations deteriorated rapidly and some football players suffered an increasing number of leg and ankle injuries; some players claimed to trip over seams. Prior to the second installation in 1972, the city did not consult with the Dolphins about the replacement; head coach Dolphins' coach [[Don Shula]] preferred a different brand, either AstroTurf or Tartan Turf.<ref name=obtamg>{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=BEFQAAAAIBAJ&sjid=tlcDAAAAIBAJ&pg=4952%2C2852896 |newspaper=Evening Independent |location=St. Petersburg, Florida |agency=Associated Press |title=OB Poly-Turf: A mean green |date=September 26, 1972 |page=1C }}</ref> The field discolored from green to blue due to the severe [[Ultraviolet|UV]] nature of the Miami sun.<ref name=trbques/><ref>[http://miamisouthpaw.blogspot.com/2009/08/ghosts-of-orange-bowl-poly-turf.html MiamiSouthpaw.blogspot.com] – "Ghosts of Orange Bowl Poly-Turf" – 2009-08</ref>
===Return to natural grass=== The city removed the Poly-Turf in 1976 and re-installed natural grass, a special type known as Prescription Athletic Turf (PAT),<ref name=obswptf>{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=La0yAAAAIBAJ&sjid=l-oFAAAAIBAJ&pg=2426%2C4942873 |newspaper=Miami News |title=Orange Bowl sticks with Poly-Turf |date=December 20, 1975 |page=2B }}</ref><ref name=patusedsv>{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=sLwyAAAAIBAJ&sjid=u-oFAAAAIBAJ&pg=1244%2C3248792 |newspaper=Miami News |last=Nobles |first=Charlie |title=PAT can be used to soften visitors |date=January 28, 1976 |page=1C }}</ref><ref name=dffbwor>{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=W2MzAAAAIBAJ&sjid=aOoFAAAAIBAJ&pg=5952%2C5005180 |newspaper=Miami News |last=Nobles |first=Charlie |title=Dolphins find fewer bugs without rug as Vikings visit |date=July 31, 1976 |page=1B}}</ref> which remained until the stadium's closure in early 2008. As late as December 1975, the city had planned to retain the Poly-Turf for the 1976 season,<ref name=obswptf/> but that decision was changed a few weeks later, prior to the Super Bowl.<ref name=ibtgraob/><ref name=obwistgr>{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=i6EyAAAAIBAJ&sjid=oOoFAAAAIBAJ&pg=950%2C4246875 |newspaper=Miami News |last=Nobles |first=Charlie |title=Orange Bowl will install grass |date=February 10, 1976 |page=1C }}</ref><ref name=ljwout>{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=6BIyAAAAIBAJ&sjid=cOUFAAAAIBAJ&pg=2447%2C1750043 |newspaper=Lawrence Journal World |location=Kansas |title=Orange Bowl taking out Poly Turf |date=February 14, 1976 |page=17}}</ref>
The Orange Bowl became the first major football venue to replace its artificial turf with natural grass, and it was the third NFL stadium to install Prescription Athletic Turf; Denver's [[Mile High Stadium]] and Washington's [[Robert F. Kennedy Memorial Stadium|RFK Stadium]] installed PAT fields a year earlier in the spring of 1975.<ref name=patusedsv/>
==Other installations== Other [[National Football League|NFL]] stadiums which installed Poly-Turf included [[Schaefer Stadium]], opened in 1971 for the [[1971 New England Patriots season|New England Patriots]],<ref name=rugsi/> and [[Tulane Stadium]] in [[New Orleans]], home of the [[New Orleans Saints|Saints]], [[Tulane Green Wave football|Tulane University]], and the [[Sugar Bowl]]. Notable college stadiums included [[Legion Field]] in [[Birmingham, Alabama]]<ref name="P-TLegion">{{cite news |agency=Associated Press |title=Poly-Turf for Legion |page=7 |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=2kUgAAAAIBAJ&sjid=EpwEAAAAIBAJ&pg=3431%2C3964209 |publisher=Google News Archives |newspaper=The Tuscaloosa News |date=May 19, 1970 |accessdate=January 20, 2014}}</ref> and [[Alumni Stadium]] at [[Boston College]].<ref name=therelmg>{{cite magazine |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hywEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA259&lpg=PA259 |magazine=Texas Monthly |last=Reid |first=Jan |title=The real mean green |date=December 1979 |page=153}}</ref>
American Biltrite ceased production of Poly-Turf in 1973; 3M stopped the manufacture of its Tartan Turf in 1974, citing rising oil prices.<ref name=tyofphfl/> This left AstroTurf as the only major manufacturer of artificial turf until [[FieldTurf]] was started in the late 1990s.<ref>''[http://www.pacosm.com/specialtopics/Living%20with%20Artificial%20Grass%20%20A%20Knowledge%20Update.%20Part%201.%20Basic%20Science.%20AJSM%201990,%20vol.%2018%20p.406.pdf "Living with Artificial Grass"] ''American Journal of Sports Medicine'' vol. 18, no. 4, 1990-07</ref>
==References== {{reflist|2}}
[[Category:Artificial turf]]

{{other uses}} {{Distinguish|sling (weapon)|catapult}}[[File:Slingshot (weapon).png|thumb|200px|Simple slingshot]]
A '''gallybander''' '''slingshot''' or '''catapult''' ([[wikt:catapult#en-N |UK]]), '''ging''' (primarily Australian and New Zealand), '''shanghai''' (Australian), '''kettie''' (South Africa), is normally a small hand-powered projectile [[weapon]]. The classic form consists of a Y-shaped frame held in the off hand ([[handedness |nondominant hand]]), with two [[natural rubber | natural-rubber]] strips attached to the uprights. The other ends of the strips lead back to a pocket that holds the [[projectile]]. The [[dominant hand]] grasps the pocket and draws it back to the desired extent to provide power for the projectile—up to a full span of the arm with sufficiently long bands.
==Use and history== Slingshots depend on strong [[Elasticity (physics)|elastic]] materials, typically [[vulcanization|vulcanized]] [[natural rubber]] or the equivalent, and thus date no earlier than the invention of vulcanized rubber by [[Charles Goodyear]] in 1839 (patented in 1844). By 1860, this "new engine" had already established a reputation for juvenile use in vandalism. For much of their early history, slingshots were a "do-it-yourself" item, typically made from a forked branch to form the "Y" shaped handle, with rubber strips sliced from items as [[Tire#Inner tube|inner tubes]] or other sources of good vulcanized rubber and firing suitably sized stones.
While early slingshots were most associated with young vandals, they were also capable hunting arms in the hands of a skilled user. Firing projectiles, such as [[lead]] [[musket]] balls, [[Shotgun shell#Buckshot|buckshot]], [[steel]] [[ball bearing]]s, [[Pellet (air gun)|air gun pellets]], or small [[Nail (fastener)|nails]], slingshot was capable of taking game such as quail, pheasant, rabbit, dove, and squirrel. Placing multiple balls in the pouch produces a [[shotgun]] effect, such as firing a dozen [[BB gun|BBs]] at a time for hunting small birds. With the addition of a suitable rest, the slingshot can also be used to shoot [[arrow]]s, allowing the hunting of medium-sized game at short ranges.<ref name=whamo_book>{{cite book |title=Wham-O Hunting Slingshot |url=http://www.melchiormenzel.de/booklets_whamo.html |publisher=Wham-O Manufacturing Co. |year=1963}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |journal=Illustrated World |volume=37| issue = 1 |page=318 |date=March 1922 |publisher=R. T. Miller Jr. |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ufbNAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA318|title=How to Make a Slingshot for an Arrow}}</ref><ref name=mmrubber>{{cite web |url=http://www.melchiormenzel.de/making_rubber_materials.html |title=Rubber Bands |author="Mel" Melchior}}</ref>
While commercially made slingshots date from at least 1918, with the introduction of the Zip-Zip, a cast iron model,<ref>{{cite web |title=The ZipZip |url=http://www.melchiormenzel.de/slingshots_old_zipzip.html |author="Mel" Melchior}}</ref> it was not until the post [[World War II]] years saw a surge in the popularity, and legitimacy, of slingshots. They were still primarily a home-built proposition; a 1946 [[Popular Science]] article details a slingshot builder and hunter using home-built slingshots made from forked [[Cornus (genus)|dogwood]] sticks to take small game at ranges of up to {{convert|30|ft|m|abbr=on|order=flip|0}} with No. 0 lead buckshot ({{convert|0.32|in|mm|0|abbr=on|disp=sqbr|order=flip}} diameter).<ref name=popsci>{{cite journal |journal=Popular Science |title=Rubber-Band Sharpshooter |date=August 1946 |author=Tom Cushing |pages=154–155 |url=http://blog.modernmechanix.com/2007/08/05/rubber-band-sharpshooter}}</ref>
The [[Wham-O]] company, founded in 1948, was named after their first product, the Wham-O slingshot. It was made of [[Fraxinus|ash wood]] and used flat rubber bands. The Wham-O was suitable for hunting with a draw weight of up to {{convert|45|lbf|N|abbr=off|lk=on|order=flip}}, and was available with an arrow rest.<ref name=whamo_book /><ref name=giantkiller>{{cite journal |journal=Mechanix Illustrated |title=Return of the Giant Killer |date=April 1951 |author=Robert Hertzberg |url=http://blog.modernmechanix.com/2007/01/12/return-of-the-giant-killer/}}</ref>
The 1940s also saw the creation of the National Slingshot Association, headquartered in [[San Marino, California]], which organised slingshot clubs and competitions nationwide. Despite the slingshot's reputation as a tool of juvenile delinquents, the NSA reported that 80% of slingshot sales were to men over 30 years old, many of them professionals. John Milligan, a part-time manufacturer of the [[aluminium]]-framed John Milligan Special, a hunting slingshot, reported that about a third of his customers were physicians.<ref name=giantkiller />
The middle 1950s saw two major innovations in slingshot manufacture, typified by the Wrist-Rocket Company of [[Columbus, Nebraska]], later renamed Trumark. The Wrist-Rocket was made from bent aluminium alloy rods that formed not only the handle and fork, but also a brace that extended backwards over the wrist, and provided support on the forearm to counter the [[torque]] of the bands. The Wrist-Rocket also used surgical rubber tubing rather than flat bands, attached to the backwards-facing fork ends by sliding the tubing ends over the tips of the forks, where it was held by friction or adhered with the addition of liquid rosin.<ref name=trumark>{{cite web |url=http://www.slingshots.com/html/slingshot-catapult-history.html |title=History of Slingshots/Catapults |author=Trumark Manufacturing Co.}}</ref>
Slingshots are also occasionally used in [[angling]] to disperse bait into the water over a wide area, so that multiple fish are attracted near the angler's [[fishing rod]].
A home-made derivative of a slingshot also exists, consisting of a rubber [[balloon]] cut in half and tied to a tubular object such as the neck of a plastic bottle, or a small pipe. The projectile is inserted through the tube and into the cut balloon, and the user stretches the balloon to launch the projectile. These so-called "balloon guns" are sometimes made as a substitute to ordinary slingshot, and is often used to create the "shotgun" effect with multiple projectiles fired at once.
<gallery widths="200px" heights="200px"> File:Arrow slingshot.jpg|A 1922 diagram showing the construction of an arrow-firing slingshot File:Folding slingshot.jpg|A folding, steel framed wrist brace slingshot using tubular bands. Marketed by the Riley Kitchen Air Rifle Company. File:Praezisionssteinschleuder.jpg|Modern slingshot with [[Human factors and ergonomics|ergonomic]] grip (center), arm support (left), stabiliser and sight (right) File:Development of clashes in Kyiv, Ukraine. Events of February 18, 2014.jpg|Violent helmeted protester fires a slingshot during [[2014 Ukrainian revolution|clashes on February 18, 2014]], in Kiev, Ukraine </gallery>
==Record power shot== The world record for the most energetic shot with a handheld slingshot was 135 [[Joule]]s. It was shot with a forward extended slingshot, also known as a "starship", which achieves more power by increasing draw length.<ref>Monster Slingshot New World Record Shot https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pAwTfAMHCG0</ref>
==Military use== Slingshots have been used as military weapons, but primarily by guerrilla forces due to the primitive resources and technology required to construct one. Such guerrilla groups included the [[Irish Republican Army]]; prior to the [[2003 invasion of Iraq]], [[Saddam Hussein]] released a [[propaganda]] video demonstrating slingshots as a possible [[Insurgency weapons and tactics|insurgency weapon]] for use against invading forces.<ref>{{Cite news | last = Shane | first = Scott | coauthors = | title = In Video, Hussein Uses Slingshots and Bows to Rally Iraqis for War | newspaper = [[The New York Times]] | location = | pages = | language = | publisher = | date = 2006-11-24 | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2006/11/24/world/middleeast/24saddam.html | accessdate = 2009-12-21}}</ref>
Slingshots have also been used by the military to launch [[unmanned aerial vehicle]]s (UAVs). Two crew members form the fork, with an elastic cord stretched between them to provide power to launch the small aircraft.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://usmilitary.about.com/od/afweapons/a/sfuav.htm |title=Security Forces Unmanned Aerial Vehicles |publisher=Air Force News Service |author=Tech. Sgt. Paul Dean |date=April 5, 2011}}</ref>
On the [[Battle of Marawi]], the soldiers of the Philippine Army's elite [[1st Scout Ranger Regiment|Scout Rangers]] were observed using slingshots with grenades as an improvised mortar to eliminate the [[Maute Group|Maute]] and [[Abu Sayyaf]] Terrorists.<ref>https://www.update.ph/2017/09/look-scout-rangers-use-improvised-giant-slingshot-in-marawi-angry-birds-style/20991</ref>
==Dangers== [[File:Slingshot band failure.jpg|thumb|right|200px|A tubular band slingshot showing a band failure at the fork.]] [[File:CPSC recall Daisy Natural.jpg|thumb|right|200px|The ball-in-band attachment method used by the recalled Daisy "Natural" line of slingshots.]]
One of the dangers inherent in slingshots is the high probability that the bands will fail. Most bands are made from [[latex]], which degrades with time and use, causing the bands to eventually fail under load.<ref name=mmrubber /><ref name=mmattach>{{cite web |url=http://www.melchiormenzel.de/making_rubber_attach.html |author=Melchior Menzel |title=Attaching the bands to the frame}}</ref> Failures at the pouch end are safest, as they result in the band rebounding away from the user. Failures at the fork end, however, send the band back towards the shooter's face, which can cause eye and facial injuries.<ref name=recall>{{cite web |url=http://www.daisy.com/natural_recall.pdf |title=Slingshots Recalled by Daisy Manufacturing Due to Risk of Serious Eye Injury |author=U.S. Consumer Product Safety Commission}}</ref> One method to minimize the chance of a fork end failure is to utilize a tapered band, thinner at the pouch end, and thicker and stronger at the fork end.<ref name=mmpouch>{{cite web |url=http://www.melchiormenzel.de/making_rubber_pouch.html |title=Attaching the pouch to the bands |author=Melchior Menzel}}</ref> Designs that use loose parts at the fork are the most dangerous, as they can result in those parts being propelled back towards the shooter's face, such as the ball attachment used in the recalled Daisy "Natural" line of slingshots (see image). The band could slip out of the slot in which it rested, and the hard ball in the tube resulted in cases of blindness and broken teeth. Daisy models using plain tubular bands were not covered in the recall, because the elastic tubing does not cause severe injuries upon failure.<ref name=recall /> Another big danger is the fork breakage, some commercial slingshots made from cheap zinc alloy may break and severely injure shooters' eyes & face. <ref name=dankung>{{cite web |url=http://www.dankung.com/article/no-dangerous-zinc-dankung-counterfeits_1302 |title=Danger of zinc alloy slingshots |author=DANKUNG}}</ref>
==Legal issues== Many jurisdictions prohibit the use of arm braced slingshots. For example, [[New York (state)|New York]] law 265.01 defines it as a Class-4 misdemeanor.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nycourts.gov/judges/cji/2-PenalLaw/265/art265hp.htm|title=Penal100|work=nycourts.gov}}</ref>
==Gallery== <gallery> File:Mexican Slingshot.jpg|Simple slingshot using a wooden fork, tubular bands, and a leather pouch. File:800px lance-pierre.jpg|Steel ball used as slingshot [[ammunition]] </gallery>
==See also== * [[Hawaiian sling]] * [[Polespear]] * [[Bullet-shooting crossbow]] * [[Trebuchet]] * [[Sling (weapon)]]
==Notes== {{Notelist}}
==References== {{Reflist}}
